com.lonepulse.robozombie.response
Class AsyncHandler<RESPONSE>

java.lang.Object
  com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.AsyncHandler<RESPONSE>

public abstract class AsyncHandler<RESPONSE>
extends Object

To be used with asynchronous request execution for retrieving the deserialized response content or for gaining insight into any failures and errors which might have occurred.

This contract defines the following callbacks:

  • onSuccess(HttpResponse, Object) - handle a successful execution
  • onFailure(HttpResponse) - handle a failed response
  • onError(InvocationException) - handle an erroneous execution

Since:
1.1.0

Version:
1.2.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

Method Detail

onSuccess

public abstract void onSuccess(org.apache.http.HttpResponse response,
                               RESPONSE content)

Use this callback to handle a successful request execution.

Successful responses contain an HTTP status code in the range 2xx.

Parameters:
response - the HttpResponse which was returned for a successful request execution

content - the deserialized response entity or an instance of the required type (e.g. the HttpEntity as specified on the request definition

Since:
1.1.0

onFailure

public void onFailure(org.apache.http.HttpResponse response)

Use this callback method to handle a failed HTTP response, in which the response code does not fall into the category 2xx.

Note that the default implementation does absolutely nothing. A minimal usage would be to override this callback, retrieve the actual status code and act upon it as necessary.

Parameters:
response - the HttpResponse with a failure status code signifying a failed request

Since:
1.1.0

onError

public void onError(InvocationException errorContext)

Use this callback to handle an erroneous request execution.

This callback will be invoked if request execution failed with an exception. It signifies a failure to execute the request or handle the response; unlike onFailure(HttpResponse) which indicates a non-successful HTTP status code.

Note that the default implementation does absolutely nothing. A minimal usage would be to override this callback and log any exceptions.

Parameters:
errorContext - the InvocationException with information on the failed request execution

Since:
1.3.0
